p: Within each site, we selected a 1â€“25 km 2 area within the interior of the marsh that contained discrete P. australis patches ( Table 1). Patches within this area were unconstrained by any physical barriers to expansion (e.g., roads, bodies of water, agricultural lands, marsh edges). These dense and usually circular patches of P. australis were readily identifiable in aerial images (color, color-infrared and black-and-white images) because of their distinct color and texture against the background marsh vegetation [31], [32].
